text: A BOY runs across the dark, flat wilderness of the North Kent marshes. A bitterly cold December evening, the misty light is fading and the boy races as if trying to outrun the darkness. This is PHILLIP PIRRIP - ‘PIP’. He is eight years-old.

A small, squat church sinks on the boggy ground. A yew tree - PIP snaps off a twig and adds it to the forlorn bunch of wintery sticks he carries. A modest tombstone bears the inscription; Here lies PHILLIP PIRRIP late of this Parish. Also GEORGIANA, wife of the above. Also ALEXANDER, BARTHOLOMEW TOBIAS, ABRAHAM, ROGER. Five tiny lozenge-shaped graves mark the childrens’ final resting place. PIP lays his modest tribute and sets about brushing away the weeds and dead-leaves that clutter the grave - - as an IMMENSE FIGURE looms behind him and snatches him up. PIP goes to cry out, but a filthy hand is clamped across his mouth as he is hoisted, weeping and struggling into the air.

Hold your noise! Hold your noise, you little devil, or I'll cut your throat! The convict is a formidable figure, immense and terrifying, his head and face brutally shaven and scarred His name is MAGWITCH, though we won’t hear this spoken aloud for some time.
Tell us your, name! Quick!
Pip!
Once more! Give it mouth!
Pip! Pip, sir!  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 2. Then PIP is flipped upside down, held by his ankles, shaken.
Got wittles on you, boy? Tell me!
No, sir! - then upright again, he’s seated on a tombstone, his tiny face held in massive, manacled hands.
What fat cheeks you ha’got. Darn me if I couldn’t eat em. Where’s your mother?
There, sir! (MAGWITCH flinches -) ‘Also Georgiana’, with my father. ‘late of this parish’. My brothers too.
An orphan, eh? Who d’you live with? That's supposin’ I let you live.
My sister, sir - Mrs Joe Gargery, wife of Joe Gargery, the blacksmith, sir...
Blacksmith, eh? (a moment) You know what a file is?
Yes, sir.
And you know what wittles is?
Yes, sir, food, sir.

(breath hot on PIP’s face) Now I ain’t alone, as you may think I am. There’s a young man hid with me in comparison with which I am an angel, has a secret way of getting at a boy, and at his heart, and at his liver, so that they may be roasted and ate. It is in vain for a boy to hide from that young man. A boy may lock his door, may tuck himself up, may draw the clothes over his head, and that young man will softly creep and creep his way to him and tear him open... (MORE)

(whispers in the ear of the terrified boy) You bring me tomorrow morning early, at yonder battery, that file and them wittles - never daring to say a word - and I will do what I can to keep that young man out of your insides. Understand? (PIP nods) Speak it out!
Yes, sir!
Now. Get you home. PIP turns, tumbles away, pausing just long enough to turn and see the convict disappear into the misty graveyard.
PIP runs towards home as fast as he can. His stride slows A gibbet hangs over the road, empty but still sinister in the gathering gloom. PIP steps warily beneath, then starts to run once again.
PIP’s home adjoins the forge. Made of wood, the house is modest but comfortable enough, and a safe refuge now. PIP barrels towards the door, and straight into -
JOE GARGERY, the blacksmith - a rich Kentish accent.
There you are! Your sister’s been out a dozen times looking for you, old chap. And on cue, a ferocious cry comes from outside.
With practiced efficiency, JOE takes a towel, wads it up, uses it to pad the back of PIP’s trousers.  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 4.

She’s on the rampage, Pip, and she’s got Tickler with her. Best get behind the door, old chap. I’1l do my best... A closer look at JOE - fair, curly hair, pale eyes, he’s large, powerfully-built man, devoid of aggression, incapable of malice. Good-natured; child-like almost. And then MRS JOE is in the room. Ferocious, black-hair, red-faced with fury.

Where have you been, you little monkey! Wearing me out with fret and worry! I said where have you been! She charges at PIP, wielding her cane, ‘Tickler’. JOE doe his best to shield PIP behind his large leg, but MRS JOE simply beats him too.
The churchyard! As it was Christmas -
The churchyard! If it weren’t for me you’d’ve been to the churchyard years ago, and stayed there! Who brought you up by hand?
You did!
And why did I do it, I should like to know!
I don’t know.
Gargery - fetch the tar water!
No need for tar water (she turns on JOE) It is Christmas, my love.

(a moment then -) Bad enough having to be a blacksmith’s wife, without having to mother you too. Ha! Churchyard! (sawing at a loaf of bread) You’1l drive me to the churchyard between you one of these days, and a precious pair you’d be without me! But you’d like that I suppose, the both of you...

And as her monologue continues, PIP slides out from his hiding place and exchanges looks with his ally JOE. A mute conversation; ‘you alright, old chap?’, ‘thank you Joe’. JOE ruffles his hair; an understanding. But MRS JOE is watching. MRS JOE. Table! Now! They take their places at the table. PIP eyes the bread. The sound of a cannon in the distance distracts JOE, and PIP snatches the bread, stows it beneath the table.
Hear that? (another distant explosion) There’s a conwict escaped off the Hulks.
What might he have done, this convict? And MRS JOE is on him again.
Murder most likely. That’s why they’re put in the Hulks, because they murder-
Murder?
- murder and rob and ask too many questions! (points the knife) Where’s that bread gone? It’s in his hand, beneath the table -

I ate it. A moment. MRS JOE glares but PIP holds his nerve and she turns. JOE regards PIP questioningly. PIP shrugs, and squeezes the bread into his pocket. INT. PIP’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 6 Hungry, terrified, PIP hides beneath the covers, thinking on murder. Every object in the small, meek attic room seems menacing, every creak seems to speak ‘murder’.PIP pulls the covers higher, squeezes his eyes shut.
The sun rising on the new day.  10 11 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 6.
Every floorboard creaks as PIP tip-toes past JOE and MRS JOE's bedroom. A glimpse through the door - his sister snoring.

PIP lifts the lid from a stoneware pot and removes a magnificent meat-pie. Brandy is poured from bottle to flask, the flask corked, the bottle now half-full. PIP thinks a moment, tops the bottle up with a filthy viscous liquid - tar water. He shakes the bottle in the hope of hiding the deception. PIP turns and jumps; a dead hare hangs from the ceiling, its glassy eyes glaring accusingly at the young thief.

Christmas Day is damp and misty as PIP hurries guiltily towards the old fort that is their rendezvous. A seated figure is visible through the mist - THE CONVICT is slumped, cold and miserable, on a stone, inspecting the wounds caused by his manacles. PIP approaches, gathers his nerves, and touches the man on hi shoulder. The figure turns - But it’s a different CONVICT; gaunt, sinister, with cruel brooding eyes and a livid bruise on his face. He swipes at PIP with his chained hands, and PIP turns an flees, the hunched figure hobbling after him, growling.
Breathless, PIP stumbles on, relieved to see that the cannibalistic young man has gone, for the moment at least But suddenly -
Well, did you bring it boy? MAGWITCH scoops PIP up into the air.
(handing over the bag) Yes, sir. Here, sir.  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 7.
And what’s in the bottle?
Brandy. Back on the ground, PIP watches MAGWITCH drain the bottle of brandy, then set about the pie, scooping great handful into his mouth, glaring about him like a starving dog protecting his food.
You brought no-one with you?
No, sir!
And asked no-one to follow?
I would not do that, sir. MAGWITCH’s eyes burn into PIP. Finally -
I believe you. A cold-hearted hound you’d be, at your time of life, to hunt down a wretch as near to death and dunghill as me. PIP, despite himself, is encouraged by the approval.
I’m glad you enjoy the pie.
Thankee, my boy, I do.
There’1l be none left for him!
For ‘him’? Who’s ‘him’?
The young man you spoke of. Who wants to eat my liver.
Oh, him? (Laughs-) He won’t want no pie.
He looked as if he did.  12 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 8.
Looked? What d’you mean, looked?
I saw him.
When?
Just now.
Where?
Down by the river.

Dressed like me? Bruised face? Here? Badly bruised? (PIP nods) Give me the file, boy! Immediately MAGWITCH is sawing wildly at his chains, oblivious to the raw red wounds about his ankles, muttering to himself. MAGWITCH (CONT’D) PIP Hunt him down like a Goodbye, then sir. A merry bloodhound I will. Let him Christmas to you! go free? Let him make a Goodbye... tool of me again and again? That villain? No, I’1l take him to the bottom of the river if I have to drag him there myself... And getting no response, PIP shrinks away into the mist. A Christmas carol, sung with great volume and little tune

A squeeze-box wheezes away. The carol is performed by MR PUMBLECHOOK and the GARGERY’s other Christmas guests; MR and MRS WOPSLE and MR and MRS HUBBLE. These clerks and tradesmen are what pass as gentle-folk in the narrow confines of the village, and MRS JOE is appropriately puffed-up. PIP does his best to slip in un-noticed, but MRS JOE sees him, and discreetly draws her finger across her neck.
Later. The Christmas dinner is laid. PUMBLECHOOK dominate the festivities, a large man with dull eyes and a mouth like a fish.
For the great feast that we are about to receive - thanks to you ma‘am - may the good lord make us truly thankful.
Amen.
Did you hear that? Be grateful!
- especially, my boy, to those as what brought you up by hand.
Why is it that the young are never grateful? A moment’s contemplation of this devastating gambit.
Naturally wicious! Mumbles of ‘true, true’! PIP is in hell, but JOE is there JUMP CUT - Meal underway, PIP picking at fat and gristle.
More gravy, old chap?
Oh, I nearly forgot! Ladies and gentleman, do leave a little room for the savoury pork pie so kindly provided for by dear Mr Pumblechook.
No more than you deserve, ma’am.
I’ll get it now. Shall I get it now? I’11l get it now. Murmurs of approval. She heads off to the larder to searc for the treasured pie, now long gone. PIP shrinks further in his seat.
You look awful white, old chap. Have some gravy —  13 14 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 10.
I often say, a slice of It’s here somewhere! savoury pork pie will lie on top of anything you care to mention and do no harm.
Wise words, as always.
Especially with a little brandy.... MRS JOE returns —
At least it was here. It’s gone! And now PUMBLECHOOK explodes into coughing and retching.
TAR WATER! In the brandy! It’s all too much. He bolts to the door, dodging MRS JOE
Come here, you little monkey! And straight into the arms of - A SERGEANT. A crowd of SOLDIERS stand behind him, rifles at the ready. In the SERGEANT’s hand, MAGWITCH’s manacles
JOE’s hammer bangs down onto glowing iron. Sparks fly. Th party guests and the SOLDIERS are clustered round the forge as the chain of the manacles is repaired

A nasty pair. Two of the most vicious characters you’d care to meet. Anybody here seen anything of any such game? (with a great hiss, the mManacles are plunged into the water) Thank you, sir. A fine job. (examines JOE’s handiwork, tests their strength.) We found them filed clean through. No matter. We'll have’em back on him soon enough. ‘Course, if any of you gentlemen fancy some sport...  15 16
17 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 11. PIP regards JOE, and the possibility of larks - then MRS JOE, still glaring dangerously. No contest -

As night creeps in, so does the fog. The SOLDIERS advance in loose formation, a long line almost lost to each other in the mist. PIP and JOE pass beneath the old gibbet, PIP regarding it with dread. A whisper -—
I hope we don’t find ‘em, Joe.
I hope so too, old chap.
The hunt continues. Voices from the mist -
Murder! Help! Help me! Murder!
Over here! They’re over here. Get some light. Torches are lit ablaze now, their sulphurous flames glowing in the fog as the soldiers, JOE and PIP head to -

A ferocious fight is taking place, with MAGWITCH looming huge and victorious over his slighter opponent. The second CONVICT’s face is a mess of mud and blood, wit a vicious gash down one side of his face, the fight so brutal that the SOLDIERS can only stand and watch, too frightened to intervene, spectators in a flame-lit arena. The SERGEANT pushes through -—  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 12.
Well what are you waiting for? Move! The SOLDIERS pull them apart, the two CONVICTS swearing and clawing at each other throughout.
I took him! Take note, I took him and gave him up to you!
Handcuffs! The CONVICTS are manacled. PIP hides behind JOE’s leg.
He tried to murder me!
Try, and not do it? I'd have killed him if I wanted, but instead I dragged him here. I took him! Let him go free? Let him profit from me, again and again?
Enough of this! Light the torches!
He tried to murder me! I should have been a dead man, if you hadn’t got here.
He lies! He’s a liar born and he’ll die a liar. Look at his face, his grovelling eyes. Look me in the eyes, villain. LOOK

MAGWITCH makes another murderous lunge at his enemy, but is pulled back and down by four of the SOLDIERS. And it’s only then, forced to the floor like a wild animal, that MAGWITCH meets PIP’s eye, sees the fear and alarm on the young boy’s face. For a moment, MAGWITCH snarls, moves towards the boy - But PIP puts his hand to his own chest, and shakes his head. ‘It wasn’t me’ — A moment, then all the fight goes out of MAGWITCH. Something almost like shame comes to his face. And he allows himself to be hauled to his feet and manacled once more.  18 19 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 13.

Silhouetted against the low winter sun, the chained men and the soldiers march on. PIP and JOE bring up the rear, following the trail of burning tar. On the estuary, sinister shapes loom on the horizon -

The prison ships; menacing hulks, lifeless, ghost ships almost, lit by sulphurous torch-light. Two rowing boats await to take the convicts back to this hell. The second CONVICT is already on his way, his bloodied face full of fear. MAGWITCH is about to be led away too, but he turns a moment and, without looking at PIP, speaks to the SERGEANT.

I wish to say something. A man can’t starve. I took - stole - some wittles up at the village. A file too, and I'll tell you from where. The blacksmith’s. (Surprise from JOE, nothing from PIP) Brandy and a pie.
Have you missed such an article as a pie, blacksmith?
My wife did.
So you're the blacksmith, are you? MAGWITCH steps towards JOE and PIP, causing the soldiers to stand. But JOE doesn’t flinch.
Then I’m sorry to say I’ve eat your pie.
God knows you’re welcome to it. We don’t know what you've done, but we wouldn’t have you starve to death for it, would us Pip? MAGWITCH looks to PIP. PIP shakes his head.

Pip.  20 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 14. The ghost of a smile, as he places the large manacled han on PIP’s head. A benediction. Then MAGWITCH is hauled away. Seated in the bow of the boat, manacled, hunched and filthy, MAGWITCH turns once more and steadily meets PIP’s eye as he is rowed off towards that wicked Noah's Ark. FADE TO BLACK.

Autumn now. Some time has passed, the marshes have lost some of their menace and the day is bright and clear as PIP lies in the long grass with JOE by his side, both concentrating hard on a slate, on which PIP chalks letter with intense concentration. JOE looks on in wonder;
I say, Pip old chap! What a scholar you are!
I should like to be, some day. Read it, Joe.
Read it. Read it.... He’s holding the slate upside down. PIP turns it and reads;
‘Mi Deer JO i opE U R KRWITE WELL i shAL SOn B HabeLL 4 2 TEEDGE U JO an WOT LARX an BLeVE ME inFXN PIP’
Why there’s a ‘J’! And an ‘0’, best ‘0’ I ever saw. Astonishing! How interesting reading is!
Perhaps I could teach you one day, Joe.
P’raps. P’raps. Though I fear I am most awful, awful dull. Not like you, young scholar! When I think back to how small and flabby and scrawny you were when I first bought you to the forge -
Joe - please!  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 15.
(a moment, then -) Ever the best of friends, ain’t us, Pip?
Ever the best of friends, Joe.
And when you’s apprenticed to me - what larks. A bellow echoes across the marshes.
She must be, what, two mile off? (PIP laughs) Best get us back then, old chap.
PIP’s head is ducked unceremoniously into a bucket of water.
Now if this boy ain’t grateful, he never will be. (PIP comes up, gasping for air) I only hope he won’t be pampered.
She ain’t in that line, mum, have no fear.
‘She’?
Well, Miss Havisham ain’t a he, is she? Even you ain't as dull as that!
Well put, ma’am. Good indeed. MRS JOE scrubs at PIP as if he were a stone floor. Soaped needed, towelled, thumped...  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 16. PIP is tugged and pulled into his best suit.
Mr Pumblechook here -
- her tenant, don’t you see.
- goes to pay his rent and Miss ‘Avisham says does he know a boy who might go and play there for her pleasure and Mr Pumblechook, being always considerate and thoughtful of us -
- no more than you deserve -
- mentions this boy, prancing here. He’s to go straightaway! For all we know our fortune might be made and all he has to do is play!
But I don’t want to... The affect on MRS JOE is startling. She reddens, clutches at her heart.
Listen to me, ungrateful wretch. D’you want to mix with people of quality and breeding, or stay here and rot with this great lumpen noodle?
Stay here?
PIP looks to JOE, but there’s nothing he can do. PIP nods in acquiescence, and the pummelling continues.
PIP sits in PUMBLECHOOK’s cart, scrubbed and trussed up i his stiffest clothes, his suit too short.
Eight times twelve?  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 17.
Ninety-six. Through twisted, overgrown parkland PIP sees the grim, dismal hulk of Satis House.
Four times seventeen? Too slow! Sixty- eight. Nine times thirteen - PUMBLECHOOK keeps up his stream of questions as they step down from the cart and approach the gates, chained shut.
One hundred and seventeen -

- minus thirty-two? Are you listening, boy? Boy? The garden of this once fine house is overgrown, the windows are either bricked up or barred, and from the outside it seems barely credible that the place could be inhabited. And yet...
What name? A silhouette, calls from a window in a clear voice.
Pumblechook!
Quite right.

Now, boy, remember your station and let your conduct be a credit unto those which brought you up by hand. And now a strikingly pretty young girl approaches, scarcely older than PIP but proud, self-assured, fearless - YOUNG ESTELLA. She regards PIP with a judgemental eye, then produces a large bunch of keys and opens the gate.
Do you wish to see Miss Havisham?
If Miss Havisham wishes to see me!  25 26 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 18.
She don’t. (The gate is closed on PUMBLECHOOK. To PIP -) Come along. And with a glance back at the indignant, excluded PUMBLECHOOK, PIP follows her into the house.

The gloomy house is lit by a great many candles. ESTELLA takes one up and leads the way. Portraits and draped furniture can be glimpsed as they make their way up a fin staircase towards a door. They stop outside.
Are you frightened?
I don’t know.
Go in then.
After you, miss. ESTELLA smiles scornfully and walks away. PIP takes a breath and pushes the door open...

The room is lit with candles, with no glimpse of daylight It is the bedroom, and MISS ELEANOR HAVISHAM sits in fron of the mirror of her dressing table. She is quite the strangest lady he - or we - have ever seen. The wedding dress, the gloves, the veil are all decayed to a yellow-grey. The bride too has taken on this ashen, sickly taint.

Come nearer. Let me look at you. PIP approaches gingerly, taking in more of the room; the stilled pendulum, the clock stopped at twenty to nine, th half-packed suitcase, the once-fine clothes now dusty and decayed.
Look at me! (He does so) You are not afraid of a woman who has never seen the sun since you were born?  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 19.
No, ma’am.
Then come closer. (her hand on her chest) Do you know what I touch here?
Your heart.
Broken! The word is spoken with a weird pride.
I sometimes have sick fancies and I have a sick fancy that I want to see some play. Play. Play! (PIP stands, frozen) Are you sullen and obstinate?

No, ma’‘am! I am very sorry for you and sorry that I can’t play. If you complain of me I will get into trouble with my sister, so I would play if I could, but it’s so new here.... She regards him. A moment. Very quiet.

So new to him, so old to me, so melancholy. Call Estella! Estella! ESTELLA is already approaching, lit by candlelight. She walks past him and straight to MISS HAVISHAM. With a strange mechanical movement, a ritual almost, ESTELLA places her head on her lap. MISS HAVISHAM picks a broach from the dressing table and places it against ESTELLA’s dress, in her hair, watching how the jewels compliment her skin.
Your own one day, my dear, and you will use it well. (she fixes the broach to ESTELLA, as if arming her) Now. Let me see you play cards with him.
But he’s a common labouring boy.  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 20.
Well? (whispered, for ESTELLA only) You can break his heart. They both look to PIP.
What do you play, boy?
Nothing but beggar my neighbour, miss.
So. Beggar him.
The card game. MISS HAVISHAM looks on.
The jack of diamonds.

‘Jack’! He calls the knaves ‘jacks’, this boy. (MISS HAVISHAM smiles) And what coarse hands he has, and what thick boots. He’s nothing but a stupid, clumsy labouring boy. Humiliated, fighting back tears, PIP looks to MISS HAVISHAM.
You say nothing of her. What do you think of her?
I don’t like to say.
Whisper in my ear. And PIP approaches, until his face is close to MISS HAVISHAM - the yellow skin, the milky eyes.
I think she is very proud.
Anything else.
I think she is very pretty.  28
Anything else?
I think she is very insulting. I think I should like to go home.
What? And never see her again? And PIP looks to ESTELLA. Beautiful. A whisper.
I think I’d like to see her again. MISS HAVISHAM smiles - she has won.
Then you shall. But when, when shall I have you here again?
Today is Wednes...
No Wednesdays, Thursdays, Fridays here, no days of the week, no weeks of the year. Come again after six days. Estella, take him down. Feed him.

PIP waits in the yard of the derelict brewery as ESTELLA approaches. She carries a tray of bread, a mug of beer which she places on the floor in front of the boy. It's as if he were a dog in disgrace. The gesture is so hurtful and humiliating that tears start in Pip’s eye. YOUNG ESTELLA sees this. With an effort PIP struggles to retain his dignity. ESTELLA merely smiles and walks away.
PIP’s slammed into the wall, MRS JOE hissing into his ear
Did you disgrace yourself?
No -
And did she pay you?  29 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 22.
No -
Or say she’d do something for us, a reward?
She wants me to return -
Then you will return, d’you hear me, you’1l return and play nicely until she sees us right. D’you understand? And she lets the shaken PIP go. JOE looks on, powerless.

A shower of sparks. PIP watches from his usual spot, taking in JOE’s thick boots, his coarse, dirty hands, the grime on his face as he hammers to the dirge-like song ‘Old Clem’. PIP holds up his own hands, examines them; the dirt under the scruffy nails. Suddenly, JOE breaks off singing.
Something wrong, old chap?
I wish you hadn’t taught me to call the knaves jacks.
What’s that, Pip? PIP pauses for a moment. Then, in a rush -
And I wish my boots weren’t so thick and my hands weren't so coarse and I wish I wasn’t common! He tries to run but JOE stops him, scoops him up -
Now, now old chap. That’s enough now, what's all this talk? ‘Common’? Who says you’s common? Tell me -
The girl, at Miss Havisham’s.  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 22a.
But you aren’t common in the least, old boy! To my mind you are most uncommon. Uncommon small and an uncommon scholar...
I am ignorant and backward, Joe.
And what of that letter you wrote, with the fine ‘J’ and the ‘0’, the most uncommon ‘O’ I ever saw...
I know nothing! You think much of me, that’s all.
And ain't that something, old sport? Ain’t that something?
31 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 23.
PIP reads aloud from a scrappy Bible -

‘,.and the Lord said unto Aaron ‘Thou and thy sons and thy father’s house.. An apple core hits him on the forehead. A classroom descending into anarchy. PIP looks to MRS WOPSLE, the ancient village teacher but she lies face down on her des snoring, entirely unaware of the chalk, conkers, shoes that fly through the air towards PIP - Rescue - BIDDY, MRS WOPSLE’s granddaughter, rushes in to calm the chaos.

Good gracious, what is going! Enough! Enough I say! BIDDY is barely eleven, scruffy, more plain than pretty, but with a humorous, pleasant, open face. An orphan, like PIP, who watches her closely now, with barely-concealed admiration.

Back to your desk, Pip. Very good. Now, let us read together - (the sleeping teacher) Quietly. ‘And the Lord said unto Aaron -  32 33 34 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 24. And while their teacher sleeps the class read aloud in a monotonous whisper. BIDDY catches PIP’s eye. She smiles.
The class files out. BIDDY looks up. PIP is waiting there
I wonder if...you might teach me.
Teach you what, Pip?
Everything. I want to know everything.
(She laughs -) Everything? Goodness, well that might take a little time. Pip, whatever for? For THIS -
YOUNG ESTELLA, austere and beautiful, opens the gate. Wordlessly, PIP follows. As they walk -
Do you know the name of the house, boy? It is Satis House.
Is that...Greek?
Greek or Latin or Hebrew or all three, for ‘enough’.
Enough House. That’s a curious name.
Don’t loiter! It meant, when it was given, that whoever had this house, could want for nothing else...

They must have been easily satisfied. The shabby remains of the HAVISHAM and POCKET families wait, and wait, and wait.  35 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 25. Three women, one man, shifty, unappealing, they regard PI as birds of prey might regard a sickly lamb.
(to ESTELLA) Is this him? Is this the boy?
(still walking) None of your business...
Well! Of all the...
Will she see us today? We have been waiting!
Waiting all morning!
We only wish to help! Smiling conspiratorially, ESTELLA whispers to PIP.
Miss Havisham’s poor relations. She calls them her vultures. Ignore them. It drives them mad. PIP glances back at the glaring relatives and smiles. A sense of mischievous solidarity with ESTELLA -
And are they your relations too?
Certainly not. I have no relations.
Then Miss Havisham is not your -
(stops suddenly, turns) Well?
Well, miss?
Am I pretty?
You are very pretty.  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 26.
Am I insulting?
Not so much as last time, no. And ESTELLA slaps him, very hard. Pip gathers himself.
Why don’t you cry?
(tearful, defiant) Because I don’t want to -
You cried last time, I saw you -
- and I‘’ll never cry for you again. ESTELLA raises her hand to strike again
Whom have we here? A large, well-dressed man - JAGGERS, MISS HAVISHAM’s solicitor. Powerful, immaculate, self-assured, he takes PIP’s chin in his large, manicured hand.
This is the boy, is it? Well I have a pretty large experience of boys, and you're a bad set of fellows. Behave yourself. (to ESTELLA) He’s to wait in the ballroom.

The door is closed on PIP. A fire has been lit in the great, grand ballroom, but the smoke hangs in the air lik Marsh mist.
